desc: To alleviate pain or suffering means to make it less intense or severe.
exam: She needed something to alleviate the pain in her back.

desc: Astrology is the study of the stars in the belief that they influence people’s lives.
exam: Jack, who studies astrology, believes that the stars can predict the future.

desc: To differentiate things or people is to show the difference between them.
exam: It was hard to differentiate between the identical twins.

desc: To disrupt something or someone is to prevent them from working.
exam: The loud crash disrupted the class lecture.

desc: An equation is a math operation to determine the value of something.
exam: I used the Pythagorean theorem to solve the equation.

desc: To err means to make a mistake.
exam: The pilot erred in his estimate of the time it would take to make the trip.

desc: When something is erroneous, it is incorrect or only partly correct.
exam: The child held the erroneous belief that time machines were real.

desc: If people or things are frantic, they behave in a wild way because they are frightened.
exam: The cat became frantic when I tried to give it a bath.

desc: The hull of a boat or tank is the main body of it.
exam: Afterthe wreckatsea, the ship’s hull was the last part to sink.

desc: When an action is inadvertent, it is done without realizing what you are doing.
exam: She made an inadvertent error when she knocked over the nail polish.

desc: To improvise something is to do it with whatever is available or without planning.
exam: There was no meat for the pizza, so we improvised with what was in the fridge.

desc: The latitude of a place is its distance from the equator.
exam: The device was able to tell the traveler his exact latitude.

desc: A mariner is a sailor.
exam: The old mariner used his telescope to find the shore.

desc: A multitude of things or people is a very large number of them.
exam: A multitude of people were waiting at the airport.

desc: A nuisance is a person or thing that is annoying or causes a lot of problems.
exam: The teenager considered her noisy little brothers to be quite a nuisance.

desc: The permanence of something is its ability to last forever.
exam: Poor results will threaten the permanence of the new teaching system.

desc: To revolve around something is to keep it as the main feature or focus.
exam: My life revolves around sports.

desc: To soothe means to calm someone who is angry or upset.
exam: The mother soothed her crying baby by rocking him in her arms.

desc: If someone is stranded, they are prevented from leaving a place.
exam: When the plane left, my sister and I were stranded in China.

desc: When something is volatile, it is likely to change suddenly and unexpectedly.
exam: The volatile volcano might explode at any moment.

desc: When something is arduous, it demands great effort or labor.
exam: The explorers began their arduous hike up the steep mountain.

desc: To attain something means to gain or achieve it, often after a lot of effort.
exam: In two more years, I will attain my high school diploma.

desc: To coexist with something means to exist with it in the same time and place.
exam: Our pets coexist at our home with little or no problems.

desc: To conceive something means to be able to imagine or believe it.
exam: The child could not conceive the actual size of the Earth.

desc: When something or someone is dubious, they are not considered honest.
exam: The police thought that the man’s description of the crime was dubious.

desc: An ego is a person’s sense of their own worth.
exam: Kelly’s ego made her think that she was some kind of a superhero.

desc: Elastic is a rubber that stretches when it is pulled.
exam: He attached the elastic bungee to his legs before he jumped off the platform.

desc: An endeavor is an attempt to do something, especially something new or original.
exam: The company’s new advertising endeavor ended in a horrible failure.

desc: To engrave means to cut a design or words into the surface of something.
exam: The couple engraved their names onto the old pine tree.

desc: To excavate means to dig on land and remove dirt to look for something.
exam: The team wishes to excavate the site in hopes of finding fossils.

desc: When something is jagged, it has a tough, uneven shape or edge.
exam: The swimmer was hurt when he fell on the jagged rocks.

desc: A locale is a small area or place where something specific happens.
exam: The spa was the perfect locale for my mother to relax and enjoy her vacation.

desc: A mold is a hollow container that is used to make certain shapes.
exam: Using a cupcake mold will ensure that they come out just right.

desc: When something is outright, it is open and direct.
exam: Everyone knew that the boy’s story was an outright lie.

desc: The periphery of an area, place, or thing is the edge of it.
exam: A beautiful floral pattern is on the periphery of the stationery.

desc: Plaster is a smooth paste that gets hard when it dries.
exam: He used plaster to fill in the cracks in the old walls.

desc: A shovel is a tool with a long handle that is used for digging.
exam: The boy grabbed his shovel and got all of the snow off of the sidewalk.

desc: When something is skeletal, it relates to bones in the body.
exam: We studied the skeletal system in anatomy class.

desc: If something is terrestrial, it relates to Earth.
exam: There are billions of terrestrial life forms.

desc: When something or someone is vicious, they are violent and cruel.
exam: The vicious dog tried to bite the small child.

desc: If something or someone is absurd, they are ridiculous.
exam: That group of people making animal noises sounds completely absurd.

desc: Anemia is a blood condition that causes a person to be pale and tired.
exam: When she first developed anemia, she became tired often.

desc: The aristocracy is the highest class of people in certain societies.
exam: Most members of the aristocracy were very well-fed.

desc: An aristocrat is a person who is of the highest class in certain societies.
exam: The aristocrat did not need a job because his family was wealthy.

desc: Attire is nice or special clothing.
exam: Everyone wore their best attire to the president’s daughter’s wedding.

desc: A craze is a brief and popular activity or object.
exam: Wearing bright red socks was a craze when I was in high school.

desc: To enlarge something means to make it bigger.
exam: The classrooms were enlarged over the summer to make room for more students.

desc: An excess is an amount of something that is more than needed or wanted.
exam: Because it never got cold that winter, many stores had an excess of coats.

desc: If something is feminine, then it has qualities that are commonly related to women.
exam: Many of the older people thought his long hair made him look too feminine.

desc: A hallmark is a unique characteristic of something.
exam: Different types of pasta and tomato sauces are hallmarks of Italian food.

desc: A pad is a thick piece of soft material used to protect or clean things.
exam: Football players wear shoulder pads to keep them safe.

desc: If something is predominant, then it is the most important, common or strongest.
exam: Before cars were invented, horses were the predominant method of travel.

desc: If someone or something is reputable, then they have a good reputation.
exam: The service from the less than reputable company made her angry.

desc: Rouge is a red powder or cream used as makeup on the cheeks or lips.
exam: Even when she didn’t wear rouge, her cheeks appeared red.

desc: To signify means to be a symbol of something.
exam: A red octagon is used to signify to stop.

desc: A strap is a thin long piece of fabric used to fasten, carry, or hold something.
exam: She put the strap of her purse over her shoulder and walked out of the door.

desc: A tangle is something or many things twisted together.
exam: The laces of his shoes were in such a tangle that he could not untie them.

desc: Vanity is excessive pride or love of one’s own appearance or things one has done.
exam: Her vanity won’t allow her to pass a mirror without looking at herself.

desc: To vie for something means to compete against others for it.
exam: The three boys vied for the prize in the chemistry contest.

desc: If something or someone is vulgar, then they are rude or lacking in style.
exam: Her vulgar behavior got her into trouble with her parents.

desc: An attic is a room just below a house’s roof.
exam: There were two windows in their attic.

desc: A chunk is a thick, solid piece of something.
exam: When they broke open the rock, they saw it was filled with chunks of gold.

desc: If something is civic, then it is related to a town or city, especially its government.
exam: Most of the important civic buildings are located downtown.

desc: A descent is a movement downwards.
exam: During the space shuttle’s descent, the Earth became larger and larger.

desc: A din is loud, unpleasant, and extended noise.
exam: The din of the rusty machinery made the factory a horrible place to work.

desc: To dissatisfy someone means to fail to please them.
exam: He was dissatisfied with his meal.

desc: A fuss is excited or annoyed behavior that is not useful in any way.
exam: The child made an awful fuss because she didn’t want to go to bed.

desc: If food is gourmet, then it is nicer and more expensive than regular food.
exam: In order to get a gourmet meal, you have to eat at an expensive restaurant.

desc: If something happens hence, then it happens as a result of something.
exam: John forgot the key. Hence, we couldn’t open the door.

desc: If something is intrinsic, then it is related to the basic nature of that thing.
exam: Paper money has no intrinsic value. It is useful simply because society says it is.

desc: A kettle is a large metal pot used for boiling liquids or cooking food.
exam: The soup was being cooked in a large kettle.

desc: A ministry is a government department.
exam: The Ministry of Trade is responsible for taxing imports and exports.

desc: An ordeal is a bad experience.
exam: Driving in the snowstorm was an ordeal she’d never forget.

desc: If someone is outspoken, then they are not afraid to say what they think.
exam: She was an outspoken critic about the new banking laws.

desc: To overwork someone means to make them tired with too much work.
exam: After working for three weeks with only one day of rest, Judy was overworked.

desc: If something is particular, then it is a single, important part of a group of things.
exam: The dress shop didn’t have the particular dress she was looking for.

desc: If something is pungent, then it tastes or smells strong and sharp.
exam: The garlic made the soup taste so pungent that the chef wouldn’t serve it.

desc: To snore means to make a loud noise each time a sleeping person breathes.
exam: It was impossible to get to sleep because my husband snored.

desc: If something is done soundly, then it is done in the best or most complete way.
exam: The nearest opponent was ten meters behind. She won the race soundly.

desc: A superintendent is a person who runs a certain department or building.
exam: The superintendent decided to close the schools because of the weather.

desc: To alternate means to switch back and forth between two things.
exam: The best exercise alternates muscle and heart strengthening.

desc: If someone is apologetic, they are sorry about something.
exam: The boy felt apologetic after losing his sister’s favorite toy.

desc: If something or someone is benign, they do not hurt anyone.
exam: Many spiders look scary, but most are actually benign.

desc: To char means to burn something so that it turns black.
exam: While Frank went inside to get the mustard, he accidentally charred the hotdogs.

desc: To clarify means to make something easier to understand by explaining it.
exam: Drew tried to clarify all the functions of Michelle’s new computer.

desc: When someone’s actions are dogged, they try hard to continue something.
exam: Her dad bought her a new jacket after her dogged requests for one.

desc: Distress is the feeling of being upset or worried.
exam: Failing a class caused the student a lot of distress.

desc: To ensue means to happen after something.
exam: After a few minutes of lightening, thunder ensued.

desc: To gasp means to make a noise by quickly breathing in when surprised.
exam: John always gasps when watching a scary movie.

desc: To negotiate means to try to make an agreement through discussion.
exam: Mario and Joe took a long time negotiating the contract between the companies.

desc: An overdose is an instance of taking or having too much of something.
exam: John’s skin was burned from an overdose of sunshine.

desc: Persuasion is the act of making someone do or believe something.
exam: The persuasion of his argument convinced the customer to buy the laptop.

desc: A relay is a race in which teams of runners or swimmers race against each other.
exam: Jerry was the fastest on his team, so he ran the last part of the relay.

desc: Reluctance is a feeling of not wanting to do something.
exam: Jesse took out the trash with great reluctance.

desc: To restate something means to say it again or in a different way.
exam: Mrs. Jones restated the test question to the class.

desc: Sesame is an herb that is grown for its small seeds and its oil.
exam: I used the buns with the sesame seeds on them.

desc: To sip something means to drink a small amount at a time.
exam: Liza relaxed on the beach, sipping fruit juice through a straw.

desc: The verge is the point at which something is about to happen.
exam: Joan was on the verge of leaving her house when the phone rang.

desc: If someone is wary, they are cautious or mistrusting.
exam: She was wary of going to school because she hadn’t done her homework.

desc: To waver is to be unable to decide between two choices.
exam: I wavered between eating the apple or the cake for a snack.

desc: If something goes ashore, it goes from water to the land.
exam: After a long day of fishing, Glen pulled his boat ashore, so it wouldn’t float away.

desc: To contradict means to state the opposite of what someone else has.
exam: Ken was always fighting with his little sister because she kept contradicting him.

desc: A counterpart is something that is very similar to something else in what it does.
exam: Our manager will meet our rival company’s counterpart later today.

desc: When something or someone is devoid of a thing, they are missing it.
exam: The movie was devoid of any violence, so it was a perfect movie for the family.

desc: To diverge is to become different or to follow a different direction.
exam: The road diverged into two paths that led to our houses.

desc: To elude means to avoid being caught by something.
exam: The rabbit eluded the wolf by hiding in a bush.

desc: An embryo is a human or animal that is still growing inside its mother.
exam: Some doctors say that what a mother eats has a big effect on her embryo.

desc: To fend off something means to push it away and avoid it.
exam: Dave spent all night fending off bugs instead of sleeping.

desc: When something is fictitious, it is made up and not real.
exam: The author said that the characters in her book were completely fictitious.

desc: A gazette is a newspaper.
exam: Alice wants to write for a gazette when she’s older.

desc: If something is homogeneous, it is made up of things which are all the same.
exam: All of the houses on Victor’s block were boring and homogenous.

desc: To obstruct something means to get in its way.
exam: The car broke down on the road and obstructed traffic for hours.

desc: To plunge means to move down into something very quickly.
exam: The water in the pool was very cold, but the boy plunged in anyway.

desc: To prolong means to make something last for a longer time.
exam: Sandy walked slowly across the beach, trying to prolong her lunch break.

desc: To publicize is to make something get a lot of attention.
exam: The company publicized the job positions in the newspaper.

desc: If something is sparse, there is not very much of it in a big area.
exam: Rob spent Saturday in his garden, clearing out the sparse weeds.

desc: A surplus is an extra amount of something.
exam: The store sold their surplus items on sale.

desc: To theorize means to develop ideas about something.
exam: They enjoyed theorizing about how things worked.

desc: To verify means to find out if something is true.
exam: Julian called the movie theater to verify that the movie started at nine.

desc: If something or someone is vigorous, they use a lot of energy.
exam: Henry uses vigorous exercise to keep himself in shape.

desc: An altar is a table used in churches.
exam: The altar had many lit candles on it.

desc: Arthritis is an illness causing pain and swelling in a person’s joints.
exam: Agatha couldn’t play the piano anymore because of her arthritis.

desc: Botany is the study of plants.
exam: Gardens are the best places for botany.

desc: If something or someone is credible, they can be believed or trusted.
exam: Dick gave a credible reason for being late and didn’t get in any trouble.

desc: If someone is deceased, they are dead.
exam: We visited the graves of our deceased grandparents.

desc: Deception is the act of lying or tricking someone.
exam: The magic looked very real, but it was only deception.

desc: To decipher writing is to figure out what it says.
exam: My teacher complained that she couldn’t decipher my essay.

desc: Dung is solid waste material produced by animals.
exam: There was cow dung all over the field.

desc: Dusk is the time in the evening when it begins to get dark.
exam: After dusk, Hannah would catch fireflies in the park.

desc: To gratify someone means to please them.
exam: Bonnie was gratified after receiving her gift from her parents.

desc: To hone something is to improve it and make it very good.
exam: Lisa honed her chess skills by hours and hours of practice.

desc: To mash something is to crush it so that it is soft.
exam: We mashed the hard potatoes and served them for dinner.

desc: If something is ornate, it is decorated with a lot of fancy things.
exam: Kim’s prom dress was very expensive since it was so ornate.

desc: Pneumonia is a dangerous illness causing the lungs to fill with liquid.
exam: Elaine got pneumonia after playing outside in the rain without a coat.

desc: When someone is psychic, they know what will happen or what people think.
exam: I think my grandmother has psychic abilities because she can predict anything.

desc: If someone is psychotic, they have a very serious mental illness.
exam: The psychotic patient believed he saw things that weren’t real.

desc: The scope of something is how many people or things it relates to.
exam: Modern history has a wide scope.

desc: If something or someone is sinister, they are evil.
exam: Bad guys in most movies have sinister laughs.

desc: Strife is disagreement or fighting between people or groups.
exam: There was a lot of strife between Jim and Lisa about what TV show to watch.

desc: If something is therapeutic, it helps to cure a disease or makes you healthier.
exam: After a stressful day of working, Phoebe would take a therapeutic bath.

desc: If something is congested, it is full or blocked.
exam: Tom didn’t get home until after dark because the road was so congested.

desc: A courier is someone who takes and delivers mail or packages.
exam: Before trains, most couriers used horses to travel.

desc: To deform something means to change it from its correct or original shape.
exam: The computer program deformed the building’s picture into an unreal sight.

desc: Etiquette is the group of rules about how to be polite.
exam: When in Asian countries, bowing is a form of etiquette.

desc: If something is exclusive, it is expensive and only for rich people.
exam: The golf course was so exclusive that most people hadn’t even heard of it.

desc: Freight is a set of items carried on a train, boat, or airplane.
exam: Trade ships only carried valuable freight like silk and spices.

desc: A garment is a piece of clothing.
exam: The business man had all of his garments cleaned before the important meeting.

desc: Insomnia is a condition in which a person has difficulty sleeping.
exam: Nate’s insomnia prevented him from getting enough rest.

desc: Intuitive is knowing about something without naturally having support or proof.
exam: Rhonda had an intuitive feeling that Shane wasn’t coming to school today.

desc: If something is liable to happen, it is very likely that it will happen.
exam: During the summer months, hikers in the forest are liable to see deer and elk.

desc: To obsess about something means to think about it all of the time.
exam: After watching the Star Wars movies, Ike obsessed about becoming a Jedi.

desc: When something is overboard, it is over the side of a boat and in the water.
exam: Tom and Gary slipped on the wet floor and fell overboard.

desc: A premium is a payment that is higher than average.
exam: Tony paid for premium gas because it made his car run the best.

desc: A privilege is a special right given to only a certain person or group of people.
exam: Only the best employee had the privilege of parking in that spot.

desc: To propel something means to push or move it somewhere.
exam: The strong wind propelled the leaf through the air and across the street.

desc: To socialize is to have a good time with people.
exam: I like to socialize with my classmates after school.

desc: To suppress something means to prevent it from happening.
exam: She suppressed her urge to scream because she didn’t want to be noticed.

desc: A tram is a vehicle like a streetcar that runs on electricity above ground.
exam: I took the tram to Eighth Avenue.

desc: To unsettle someone means to make them anxious or worried.
exam: The dark clouds in the sky unsettled Beth.

desc: To warp means to become bent into the wrong shape.
exam: The woman put the clock above the fireplace, and the heat warped it.

desc: An artery is a tube that takes blood from the heart to the rest of the body.
exam: Eating healthily keeps your arteries clean, so blood can flow with ease.

desc: Deterioration is the act of becoming worse.
exam: The lack of care led to the deterioration of the house.

desc: If something or someone is elusive, they are hard to find.
exam: The elusive fish only came out at night.

desc: To forage means to look around for food.
exam: Many animals hide food in the fall since little can be foraged in winter.

desc: To impede something means to keep it from moving or going forward.
exam: The barrier impeded our ability to get closer to the building.

desc: To induce something means to make it happen.
exam: Running without good shoes may induce leg pain.

desc: If two things are inseparable, they can’t be separated.
exam: Denise and Diana have been inseparable since they first met.

desc: If something is invalid, it is not correct.
exam: The way to winning debates is to avoid invalid arguments.

desc: To magnify something means to make it look bigger than it really is.
exam: Astronomers use telescopes to magnify far-away stars.

desc: The mainstream is a group of ideas that are considered normal and accepted.
exam: Before punk rock music became part of the mainstream, only a few people liked it.

desc: A microbe is a very small living thing that often makes people sick.
exam: The first step in curing a disease is finding the microbe that causes the disease.

desc: If something is negligible, it is extremely small and not important.
exam: The amount she owed was negligible. It was less than ten cents.

desc: Paralysis is the loss of the ability to move all or part of your body.
exam: His paralysis meant that he had to use a wheelchair to get around.

desc: A pest is an animal or insect that hurts plants or food.
exam: Many farmers put up scarecrows to keep pests off of their corn.

desc: To prevail means to be accepted or very common.
exam: Unfortunately, injustice still prevails in the country’s court system.

desc: Respiration is the act of breathing.
exam: Artificial respiration is the best thing to do if someone stops breathing.

desc: To rupture means to tear or burst open.
exam: Sarah put too much water into the balloon, and it ruptured.

desc: If something or someone is savage, they are very violent or cruel.
exam: Wild animals are very savage when defending their babies.

desc: To stun someone means to make them unable to speak due to surprise or shock.
exam: Tim fell off the swing and was too stunned to cry.

desc: If one is susceptible to something like disease, they are easily harmed by it.
exam: Not eating enough vegetables makes you more susceptible to getting sick.

desc: To accumulate something is to collect a lot of it over time.
exam: The mail accumulated in their mailbox while they were on vacation.

desc: When something is aerial, it relates to being in the air or flying.
exam: The aerial photographer took pictures from the air balloon.

desc: An apparatus is a device used for a particular purpose.
exam: The campers had an apparatus that showed them their exact location.

desc: An avalanche is a large amount of snow, ice, and rock falling off a mountain.
exam: The avalanche destroyed the mountain village.

desc: Consistency is the state of always behaving in the same way.
exam: Her consistency in archery meant that our team had a chance to win.

desc: Convection is the flow of hot air through gas or liquid.
exam: The weather changed because of convection in the atmosphere.

desc: To discharge someone is to allow them to leave from a place, usually a hospital.
exam: I was discharged from the hospital after three days.

desc: When something is intact, it is complete and not damaged.
exam: Despite being over ten years old, my father’s model ship is still intact.

desc: When a person is mortal, they cannot live forever.
exam: All people are mortal.

desc: An omen is a sign of what will happen in the future.
exam: He thought that seeing a black cat in the street was an omen of bad luck.

desc: When the sky is overcast, it is full of clouds and is not sunny.
exam: The sky was overcast in the morning, but by noon it was bright again.

desc: When something is poignant, it causes a very strong feeling of sadness.
exam: The girls cried at the end of the poignant movie.

desc: A ranger is a person who protects the forest or parks.
exam: Peter wanted to be a ranger because he liked spending time outside.

desc: Rubble is piles of broken stone and wood created after a building is destroyed.
exam: There was rubble all over the city after the earthquake.

desc: To seclude someone means to keep them away from other people.
exam: She was secluded on an island for over a year.

desc: If something moves sideways, then it moves to or from the side.
exam: Jim turned sideways in order to slow down and stop his snowboard.

desc: To sob is to cry loudly.
exam: I sobbed when my youngest daughter got married.

desc: When something or someone is sober, they are serious and calm.
exam: After the funeral, everybody felt very sober.

desc: A speck is a very small mark or amount.
exam: A speck of blood appeared where the mosquito bit him.

desc: An upbringing is the way that someone is taught to behave by their parents.
exam: He had a strict upbringing and was never allowed to watch television.

desc: To advocate a plan or idea is to support or suggest it in public.
exam: The group advocated increased spending on education and schools.

desc: To authorize something means to give permission for it.
exam: The mayor authorized the construction of a new statue in the park.

desc: A civilian is someone who is not in the military.
exam: It was Todd’s job to keep civilians from entering the army facility.

desc: A commodity is something that can be bought or sold.
exam: Fran’s uncle made most of his money trading commodities.

desc: A conquest is an event by which one country takes over another country.
exam: After the conquest, the people of the small city had no freedom.

desc: To disclose something means to tell it to someone else.
exam: John came home late, so he had to disclose his activities to his wife.

desc: The dynamics of a situation are the way that parts of it affect each other.
exam: A good psychologist needs to know a lot about the dynamics of brain disorders.

desc: To enroll in something is to put one’s name on a list as a member of a group.
exam: The students had to enroll in the class one semester in advance.

desc: When someone is envious, they want something that another person has.
exam: They were envious of their neighbor’s front yard.

desc: Euphoria is a feeling of extreme happiness.
exam: The athlete felt euphoria after he won the important game.

desc: When something is festive, it is happy and related to a party or celebration.
exam: Dean’s favorite part of Christmas is the festive clothing that people wear.

desc: When someone is jolly, they are cheerful and happy.
exam: My grandmother’s jolly attitude always made me smile.

desc: Lentils are very small beans that people cook and eat.
exam: Danni made her special soup with lentils when her husband was sick.

desc: To marshal a group means to assemble them in order.
exam: The students were marshaled outside and put into groups.

desc: Morale is the amount of hope that people have during a difficult situation.
exam: To improve our family’s morale, mom suggested going on a picnic.

desc: A prophecy is a prediction about what will happen in the future.
exam: Some people believe that prophecies are actually true.

desc: A sage is someone who is very wise.
exam: Hal always visited the local sage for help with love.

desc: A senate is a part of the government in some countries.
exam: Everybody liked Caroline and chose her to speak for them in the senate.

desc: A sentiment is an opinion based on your feelings.
exam: Tess told everyone at the table her sentiments about eating meat.

desc: Unrest is a state of anger about something among the people in a place.
exam: High taxes caused much of the unrest that led to the Revolutionary War.

desc: To adorn something means to make it more beautiful by decorating it.
exam: Small glass beads adorned the vase.

desc: Bliss is a state of complete happiness.
exam: Every time he sees his girlfriend, he feels a sense of bliss.

desc: A butler is the most important male servant in a wealthy house.
exam: Whenever he needed something, he rang a bell, and the butler appeared.

desc: A cramp is a strong pain caused by a muscle after a lot of physical use.
exam: After the marathon, Jenny got a terrible cramp in her calf muscle.

desc: When a building is dilapidated, it is old and in bad condition.
exam: Paint peeled off of the old dilapidated apartment building.

desc: To evoke a memory or emotion means to make it occur.
exam: The picture evoked memories of when grandmother was a girl.

desc: A farewell is an instance of saying goodbye or a way to say it.
exam: She got on the plane after we said our farewells.

desc: A faucet is a device that controls the flow of a liquid or gas.
exam: Turn off the faucet when you are done brushing your teeth.

desc: Filth is a large amount of dirt or dirty things that disgust you.

exam: There was an interchange of ideas between the groups.

desc: A locker is a small cabinet with a lock where people store their possessions.
exam: I keep my school books in my locker.

desc: When something is multicultural, it relates to many different cultures.
exam: Everyone was welcomed to attend the multicultural celebration.

desc: An omission is something that has been left out or not done.
exam: Mike was upset because of the omission of his name during the ceremony.

desc: To oversee something means to make sure that it is being done properly.
exam: His job was to oversee the progress of the construction project.

desc: To pierce something means to make a hole in it using a sharp object.
exam: The arrow pierced the target in the very center.

desc: To replicate something is to do it in the exact same way as someone before.
exam: I would love to replicate my father’s achievements in school.

desc: When something is wavy, it is not straight but has a series of curves.
exam: The child drew wavy lines all over the piece of paper.

desc: To abide by something, like a rule, means to obey it.
exam: If you want to play the game with us, you must be willing to abide by our rules.

desc: Conversion is the act of changing something into a different state or form.
exam: The city discussed the conversion of the parking lot into a skateboard park.

desc: To cram things means to put them into a place that can barely contain them.
exam: He crammed all of his shirts into the top drawer of the dresser.

desc: To defer means to arrange for an action to happen at a later time.
exam: The girl was very sleepy, so she chose to defer her bath until morning.

desc: To export products means to sell them to other countries.
exam: The United States exports many cereals and grains.

desc: Fumes are unhealthy smoke and gases that are made by fires or chemicals.
exam: The engine put unpleasant, black fumes into the air.

desc: When something is habitual, it is a behavior that a person usually does or has.
exam: The man was a habitual liar who was incapable of being honest with the police.

desc: To justify something means to show or prove that it is necessary.
exam: The government tried to justify its decision to bring the country into a war.

desc: Output is the amount of something that a person or thing produces.
exam: The boss hired more workers to increase the factory’s output of products.

desc: Overpopulation is the state of having too many people in an area.
exam: The organization is concerned with overpopulation of the world.

desc: A patent is a right to be the only person allowed to make or sell a new product.
exam: He quickly established a patent for his brilliant invention.

desc: To penalize someone means to punish him or her.
exam: The team was penalized when they broke the rules.

desc: Petroleum is a liquid natural resource from which many fuels are made.
exam: The petroleum at that factory is used to make gasoline.

desc: A prototype is a new machine that is not ready to be made in large quantities.
exam: He introduced his prototype to the motorcycle company.

desc: A scrap of something is a small amount of it.
exam: Chris liked to use many scraps of paper when thinking up ideas.

desc: A sector is a part of a country’s economy in a specific type of industry.
exam: We learned about just a few of the factories within the manufacturing sector.

desc: To subscribe to something is to agree or to concur with it.
exam: She subscribed to the view that musical education should be kept in schools.

desc: To subsist means to have the food, water, and money needed to stay alive.
exam: Some people are forced to subsist on only a few dollars a month.

desc: To suspend something means to delay or stop it from happening for a while.
exam: The oil company suspended production until it was sure the factory was safe.

desc: A synthesis is a combination of different ideas or styles.
exam: The band’s music was a synthesis of many different musical genres.

desc: An acrobat is a person who entertains people by doing amazing physical things.
exam: There were acrobats at the circus that did impressive and complicated jumps.

desc: Advocacy is the act of supporting or recommending something.
exam: Janine’s strong advocacy for the event made people want to attend.

desc: If something is communal, it involves a group of people.
exam: On the weekends, Theo and his son picked up trash in the communal park.

desc: If something is fluid, it is smooth and moves gracefully.
exam: Boris was a famous ballet dancer because people admired his fluid movements.

desc: To harmonize means to make different things go well together.
exam: The sweet and sour flavors of the dish harmonized well and tasted great.

desc: If someone is industrious, they work hard.
exam: Dennis was very industrious, so he never had problems finding a job.

desc: When someone is inventive, they are good at creating new things.
exam: The inventive student built a robot to help her with her chores.

desc: If something is judicial, it is related to judges or courts of law.
exam: The laws changed the way the judicial system was structured.

desc: Mandarin is one of the two main Chinese languages.
exam: Although John’s parents both spoke Mandarin, he could only speak English.

desc: If something is metropolitan, it relates to a large city.
exam: All of the metropolitan excitement of New York City made Rufus nervous.

desc: To mimic something means to copy the way it sounds or moves.
exam: The hunter mimicked a duck’s call and shot the two ducks that called back.

desc: When something is misguided, it is based on bad judgment or wrong beliefs.
exam: The snake bit Molly during her misguided attempt to grab it.

desc: To rehearse means to practice and prepare for a performance in front of people.
exam: Vick’s band rehearsed all week before their first show.

desc: To scorn someone means to behave without respect toward them.
exam: The criminal was scorned by everyone in the community.

desc: If something is sensory, it is related to the senses.
exam: Iris and Eric preferred the sensory thrill of watching movies in the theater.

desc: If something is staple, it is standard or basic.
exam: Hamburgers, steaks and hotdogs are staple foods to cook on a grill.

desc: A statute is a law that is official and has been written down.
exam: The new statute made it illegal to walk dogs in the park.

desc: A veteran is someone who has a lot of experience doing something.
exam: Hank was the team veteran and had played in more games than anyone else.

desc: A villain is an evil person who breaks the law or hurts others.
exam: The villain escaped with half of my family’s valuables.

desc: A vine is a plant that has long, twisting stems and climbs upward.
exam: The branches of the trees were covered with vines.

desc: To constrain something means to limit its development.
exam: Jim cannot join us because he is constrained by previous plans.

desc: A depot is a bus or train station.
exam: He waited for his mother to arrive at the depot.

desc: To emulate people means to imitate them because they are greatly admired.
exam: As a small boy, he always tried to emulate his big brother.

desc: The forefinger is the finger between one’s thumb and middle finger.
exam: He shouted, “ There it is!” and pointed with his forefinger.

desc: The guts are all the organs inside a person or animal.
exam: The doctor can tell you every process that happens in one’s guts.

desc: When something is inherent, it is a natural part of something else.
exam: Sweating is an inherent bodily function when exercising.

desc: To intimidate means to frighten others.
exam: My dad intimidates my friends whenever they visit.

desc: A janitor is a person who makes repairs and takes care of a building.
exam: The school janitor cleaned up the messy cafeteria.

desc: When something is moist, it is slightly wet.
exam: The ground is still moist from the rain last night.

desc: Nope is an informal way of saying “ no.”
exam: He asked if I had any money, and I had to say, “Nope. ”

desc: To prod means to push someone or something with a finger or pointed object.
exam: The bully prodded me in the chest with his finger.

desc: A ransom is a sum of money paid to a kidnapper to set the person free.
exam: He kidnapped the prince and demanded $1 million as ransom.

desc: To restrain someone or something means to use physical strength to stop them.
exam: Mike restrained Allen from reaching the door.

desc: Saliva is the watery liquid in people’s mouths that helps in digestion.
exam: The baby could not keep the saliva from dripping out of its mouth.

desc: To spit means to force liquid from one’s mouth.
exam: He emerged from the pool and spit water from his mouth.

desc: To sprint means to run very fast over a short distance.
exam: The kids didn’t want to be late to class, so they sprinted to the bus stop.

desc: A stunt is something that is done in order to get attention or publicity.
exam: The man jumped over the cars as a promotional stunt.

desc: When people are tolerant, they are approved of because they accept others.
exam: The tolerant leader thought that everyone was equal regardless of race.

desc: A vampire is a fictional monster that sleeps in a coffin and sucks people’s blood.
exam: The vampire snuck up on the woman and bit her in the neck.

desc: To yawn means to open one’s mouth wide and breathe in air.
exam: The child yawned and stretched her arms before bed for the night.

desc: An analogy is a connection made between things to show that they are similar.
exam: The doctor made an analogy between the human heart and a water pump.

desc: A person's ancestry is the series of people from whom a person descended.
exam: We studied our ancestry and found out that we are related to royalty.

desc: An archer is a person who uses a bow and arrows.
exam: The expert archer hit the target every time.

desc: A conspiracy is a secret plan made by a group of people to do something illegal.
exam: Some people think that there was a conspiracy to kill American president John Kennedy.

desc: A deputy is the second-highest-ranking person in a business or government.
exam: While the sheriff was ill, the deputy took over his duties.

desc: An earl is a nobleman from Britain.
exam: The Earl of Canterbury lived in a huge mansion.

desc: When something is fragrant, it has a pleasant smell.
exam: The girl picked delicious berries and fragrant flowers.

desc: A funnel is an object with a wide top and a narrow bottom for pouring liquids.
exam: The worker used a funnel when he poured the oil into the engine.

desc: If something is hereditary, it is a trait passed onto children from their parents.
exam: The hereditary disease affected three generations of children.

desc: A hymn is a religious song that often praises a god.
exam: The book was filled with hymns that the worshippers sang.

desc: To invert something means to turn it upside down.
exam: He inverted the bicycle to make repairs on the wheels.

desc: Prey is the animals that are hunted and eaten by another creature.
exam: The lion ran as fast as he could to catch his prey.

desc: A procession is a group of people who walk or drive in a line during a public event.
exam: The procession all celebrated when they reached the end.

desc: A prophet is a person chosen by a god to give the god’s message to people.
exam: Harold believed that he was one of the prophets of his god.

desc: When something is sarcastic, it is the opposite of what is actually meant.
exam: She hurt her mother’s feelings with her constant sarcastic remarks.

desc: Seasoning is a mix of salt, herbs, and spices that improves the taste of food.
exam: This steak tastes bland. Maybe I’ll add some seasoning to it.

desc: Sodium is an element that can be used to make substances such as salt.
exam: Sodium and chloride combine to make table salt.

desc: A tyranny is a cruel and unfair government in which one person has power.
exam: His tyranny was impossible to live under.

desc: A tyrant is someone who treats people in a cruel, harsh, and unfair way.
exam: Our boss is a tyrant. He makes us work long hours for little pay.

desc: Vinegar is a strong liquid made from sour wine that is used in cooking.
exam: Be careful because too much vinegar will ruin the recipe.

desc: If something is adjoining, it is next to or joined with a building, or room.
exam: I couldn’t sleep because the people in the adjoining room were loud.

desc: To allege something is to say that it is true without offering proof.
exam: The little girl had alleged that her older brother hid her favorite doll.

desc: An arch is a curved opening formed under a structure such as a bridge or doorway.
exam: The arch of the bridge was not high enough for the tall boat to pass underneath.

desc: To assemble means to get together in one place.
exam: The parents assembled to discuss ways to improve their children’s education.

desc: A casualty is a person killed or injured in a war or an accident.
exam: The only casualty in the car accident was a woman who broke her arm.

desc: To erect something means to build it.
exam: The king erected two towers on the north and south sides of his castle.

desc: If something is foul, then it is not pleasant or enjoyable.
exam: He wouldn’t let his dog drink from the water because it had a foul smell.

desc: A hectare is a unit of measure equal to 10,000 square meters.
exam: His family farm covered many hectares.

desc: To heighten an emotion means to increase the intensity of it.
exam: The pleasant music heightened their enjoyment of the wonderful dinner.

desc: Hospitality is friendly behavior and entertainment given to guests or strangers.
exam: The travelers were amazed at the hospitality given them by the hotel’s staff.

desc: A mansion is a large and expensive home.
exam: The mansion had thirty bedrooms, two kitchens, and a pool.

desc: To outnumber a group means to have a greater number than it.
exam: The girls outnumbered the boys at the school by four to one.

desc: If someone is overjoyed, then they are extremely happy.
exam: He was overjoyed by the news of his promotion.

desc: A pasture is an area of land covered with grass for animals to use as food.
exam: The sheep were taken to a pasture where there was more grass.

desc: A petition is a written request asking an authority to do something.
exam: The citizens all signed a petition asking the mayor to repair the sidewalks.

desc: To renovate a building means to repair it or build new structures on it.
exam: The old fire station was renovated into an apartment building.

desc: To revise something means to change or update it to make it better.
exam: When the editor discovered certain facts were wrong, he revised the book.

desc: A slab is a large, thick, flat piece of stone, concrete, metal, or wood.
exam: I looked at various slabs of stone to decorate my house.

desc: A terrace is an open area that is connected to a house or an apartment.
exam: In the afternoons, she liked to sit on the terrace and check her email.

desc: Turf is a section of grass and the dirt in which it grows.
exam: After the game, the turf looked ragged.

desc: If something is analogous to another thing, then it is like it in certain ways.
exam: The relationship with his teacher was analogous to that of a son and mother.

desc: Binoculars are a device used for seeing things that are far away.
exam: He could see the ship on the horizon only if he used his binoculars.

desc: The bulk of something is its great size.
exam: The large elephant moved its bulk with legs as strong as tree trunks.

desc: If something comprises something else, it consists of or is made up of it.
exam: Our school’s football team is mostly comprised with seniors.

desc: To depict something means to show or portray it, often using art.
exam: The statue’s face depicted the general’s determination and courage.

desc: If something is dual, then it is made up of two parts.
exam: The room had a dual function. It was a living room, but at night it was a bedroom.

desc: Fahrenheit temperature is a scale where water freezes at 32° and boils at 212°.
exam: When the temperature dropped to 32° Fahrenheit, it started snowing.

desc: To fulfill something means to achieve or finish it.
exam: The professor did not fulfill his promise not to miss a single class.

desc: A grove is a small group of trees.
exam: All the trees in this grove are apple trees.

desc: Ore is the raw form of rock or material from which a valuable metal is taken.
exam: The factory melted the ore and used it to make iron products.

desc: The outback is the wild inland region of Australia where very few people live.
exam: Many Australian farmers use the outback to raise cattle.

desc: To outweigh something means to exceed it in value, amount, or importance.
exam: Finding a warm place to sleep outweighed the need to find something to eat.

desc: A paradox is a true statement or real event that seems illogical.
exam: The paradox of her work was that the less she worked, the more she got done.

desc: A pier is a structure that extends into a body of water.
exam: If you want to catch bigger fish, then go to the far end of the pier.

desc: A shortcut is a route that is shorter than the main route.
exam: We got to the house first because we took a shortcut through the forest.

desc: A tariff is a tax or fee paid on certain imports or exports.
exam: Our tariff on imported wool makes foreign wool more expensive.

desc: A thermometer is a device that measures temperature.
exam: The thermometer outside the window indicated that it was a hot day today.

desc: To tilt something means to tip it into a sloping position.
exam: She tilted her glass and almost spilled some of the wine inside.

desc: If a statement is vice versa, then its two main ideas are switched with one another.
exam: Students learn from their teachers, and vice versa.

desc: The whereabouts of someone or something is the place where they are.
exam: The police looked for the lost dog, but its whereabouts were still unknown.

desc: Amber is a hard, yellowish material that comes from trees.
exam: The necklace was made from pieces of amber.

desc: Charcoal is a black material that is used as fuel for fire.
exam: There was burnt charcoal left on the ground from an old fire.

desc: A columnist is a writer who creates articles about a particular subject.
exam: The columnist won praise for his articles about life on the farm.

desc: When someone is courteous, they are polite and respectful.
exam: The mother asked her family to be courteous to their guests.

desc: Credentials are the proof of someone’s experience or ability to do something.
exam: The mechanic hung his credentials on his office wall.

desc: A cricket is an insect that makes loud noises, usually at night.
exam: In the country, we could see the stars and hear the crickets at night.

desc: A delta is flat area where a river splits into smaller rivers that flow into the sea.
exam: The archeologists found many ancient materials in the delta of the Nile River.

desc: Detergent is soap that is used to clean clothes or dishes.
exam: My brother added too much detergent to the wash, and bubbles got all over the floor.

desc: A euphemism is a term that is used in place of a mean or unpleasant word.
exam: “Window maintenance officer” is a euphemism for a window washer.

desc: To expire is to no longer be effective because its use has come to an end.
exam: The man’s driver’s license was going to expire in two days.

desc: Granite is a very hard type of rock that is often black or pink.
exam: The kitchen counter was made of granite.

desc: Gravel is a combination of small stones mixed with sand.
exam: The ground around the swing set was covered with gravel.

desc: To haunt is to cause problems or negative thoughts over a long period of time.
exam: His thoughts about his scary dream haunted him for weeks.

desc: When someone is liberal, they accept different ideas and people.
exam: My grandparents aren’t as liberal as my parents.

desc: A maze is a system of paths that is complicated and easy to get lost in.
exam: We got lost in the maze in the garden.

desc: Moss is a small green or yellow plant that grows on wet dirt, rocks, or tree trunks.
exam: Be careful not to slip on the moss that’s covering those rocks.

desc: A pebble is a small, round stone.
exam: We threw pebbles into the lake to make the water splash.

desc: When a bird pecks, it bites or hits something with its beak.
exam: The birds pecked at the seeds on the ground.

desc: A reservoir is a place for storing water for a town to use.
exam: If it doesn’t rain soon, the reservoir is going to dry up completely.

desc: A streak is a long, thin mark that is easy to see.
exam: Her hair was brown except for a streak which she dyed blonde.
